docs.lead_paragraph: Saying that New Jersey's 12 largest health maintenance organizations fail to provide adequate preventive health care, the state's Health Commissioner ordered the companies today to improve services like cancer screenings and childhood immunizations by 2000. The order, the first of its kind in the state, was prompted by a report released today by the State Department of Health and Senior Services, which found, among other things, that one-third of children enrolled last year in the state's 20 largest managed-care plans had not received recommended doses of vaccines by age 2.

headline.main: Trenton Cites Inadequate Care In Ordering H.M.O. Changes

docs.abstract: New Jersey Health Comr Leo Fishman, saying that state's 12 largest health maintenance organizations fail to provide adequate preventive health care, orders companies to improve services like cancer screenings and childhood immunizations by 2000 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lenny Dykstra, the fidgety, fiery leadoff hitter and center fielder known as Nails, retired yesterday after failing to come back from a debilitating back condition. Dykstra, 35, asked the Philadelphia Phillies to place him on the voluntary retired list rather than become a free agent yesterday, the final day for players to file.
docs.abstract: Lenny Dykstra, Philadelphia Phillies outfielder, retires (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: State regulators and the medical branch of the H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey have reached a ''standstill agreement'' that will stave off a state takeover of H.I.P., New Jersey's fourth largest health maintenance organization, for at least two weeks. Last week officials of the state Banking and Insurance Department, citing mounting deficits of up to $20 million in the operations of the 194,000-member health maintenance organization, announced that they were moving to take over the company's operations and end its contract with Pinnacle Health Enterprises, which last year purchased all of H.I.P.'s clinics and now provides medical and billing services to the plan and its members.

headline.main: Pact Reached to Stall Takeover of an H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just what the N.B.A. needs: more unionized employees. W.N.B.A. players voted overwhelmingly yesterday to have the National Basketball Players Association represent them, thereby aligning with the same union that is negotiating on behalf of locked-out N.B.A. players.

docs.lead_paragraph: Still exultant from his victory in the bruising Senate race, Representative Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that education, health care and campaign finance reform would be among his top priorities in Washington next year, and he vowed to keep his family in Brooklyn because he did not want to lose touch with his constituents. In the first of several days in which Mr. Schumer plans to crisscross the state thanking voters, the nine-term Democratic Congressman greeted commuters near his home in Park Slope, held a lengthy news conference in Manhattan, made a surprise appearance at a teachers' union meeting and read the top-10 list on ''Late Show With David Letterman.''

headline.main: Looking Jubilant, if Bleary-Eyed, Schumer Sets His Priorities for the Senate
headline.kicker: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE SENATOR-ELECT

docs.lead_paragraph: In the race for senator, John Edwards, a telegenic trial lawyer who specializes in personal injury cases, defeated a two-term Republican incumbent, Lauch Faircloth, who made an emotional concession speech. Mr. Faircloth ran attack ads picturing Mr. Edwards with the President and calling him a ''Clinton liberal,'' and arguing that Mr. Edwards had done nothing productive, only sued people. The incumbent also said the White House wanted him replaced by a Democrat to keep from having the Senate vote to remove Mr. Clinton from office.

headline.kicker: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- SOUTH

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of his 18 years in Washington, Alfonse M. D'Amato has been the Senator who never quite fit in. He was a conservative from a state of moderates and liberals, a machine-bred politician in an institution sprinkled heavily with Ivy League-trained debaters, a colorful showman whose predecessors and colleagues, from Herbert H. Lehman to Daniel Patrick Moynihan, were more muted and highbrow. But until yesterday, Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, had confounded his enemies time and again with sheer wiliness, energy and gall. Once the outsider, he had become the consummate Senate inside player. Dogged by ethics investigations, he had turned inquisitor into President Clinton's Whitewater dealings. Dismissed by his critics as a clown, he had learned to champion the hopes and resentments of suburban and upstate voters who had carried him to victory three times before.

headline.main: D'Amato Fails, Finally, To Confound Rivals
headline.kicker: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE DEFEAT

docs.abstract: News analysis discusses Repr Charles E Schumer's victory over Sen Alfonse D'Amato in New York Senate race; political analysts say that combination of factors--strength of Schumer's candidacy, his financial support, years of investigation into D'Amato's ethics and D'Amato's numerous gaffes--had made the 3-time Republican Senator dangerously unpopular; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Are there rules of thumb to guide parents checking a baby sitter's references? How does one get a preschooler to clean her room? Are there ways to make a new teen-age driver safer? Parents by the thousands, as well as teachers, school administrators and community workers, are finding expert advice on these and almost any other question on the National Parent Information Network, available on the Internet, and through a toll-free telephone call. The project, at the University of Illinois, is being financed by the Federal Department of Education.

headline.main: Where Parents (at Home) Can Go for Expert Advice on Child Rearing

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats regained a one-seat majority in New Jersey's Congressional delegation today, as Rush Holt capitalized on Republican Representative Mike Pappas's vocal support of Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr to win a narrow victory in the 12th District. Mr. Holt, a physicist from Pennigton, hammered away at Mr. Pappas for his outspoken criticism of President Clinton in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal. After public opinion polls showed that Mr. Clinton's support remained strong in New Jersey despite the Independent Counsel's investigation, Mr. Holt's campaign aired an assortment of radio and television ads featuring Mr. Pappas singing Mr. Starr's praises on the floor of the Congress, to the tune of ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.''

headline.main: Incumbents Prevail in 12 of 13 Districts Amid Very Low Voter Turnout
headline.kicker: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: AROUND THE REGION -- THE CONGRESS
